rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 10–28
rsbNotes.text:
10:1–28:27 The Divided Kingdom. In this section the writer makes use of 1 Kin. 12–2 Kin. 17. His record of the period of the divided monarchy does not rehearse the harsh condemnation of the northern tribes found in Kings, focusing instead on events in Judah where the temple was and the Davidic king lived. Throughout this section, the writer reports how the conditions in the kingdom depended on the nation’s faithfulness to God. As readers considered these events, they could see clearly the choices for blessing and curse in their own day.

In telling about Rehoboam’s kingship, the writer makes broad use of Kings (cf. 10:1–11:4 with 1 Kin. 12:1–24; 12:9–16 with 1 Kin. 14:21, 25–31), while presenting the material in accord with his own theological understanding and emphasis. The account is presented in two parts (chs. 10; 11 and 12:1–14), each part narrating a problematic situation, prophetic encounter, and divine blessing. The conclusion is a notice of his wars with Jeroboam and his death (12:15, 16). The chapters impress on the readers God’s curse against pride and infidelity and the benefits of living in humility and obedience to the prophetic word (20:20 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 13:1–14:1
rsbNotes.text: 13:1–14:1 The account of Abijah’s reign in Chronicles (13:2–21) differs considerably from that in Kings (1 Kin. 15:3–5). Chronicles emphasizes the positive side of Abijah’s reign while the writer of Kings focuses on the negative side (1 Kin. 15:3). Chronicles reports Abijah’s speech against the northern kingdom (13:4–12) and his prayerful reliance on God in battle (13:14).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 14:1
rsbNotes.text: 14:1 the land had rest. See note 1 Chr. 22:9.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 14:2–16:14
rsbNotes.text: 14:2–16:14 This account of Asa’s reign is considerably longer than that of 1 Kin. 15:9–24. Asa’s reign is presented in two parts: years of fidelity and blessing (14:2–15:19) and later years of infidelity and curse (ch. 16). These two parts form a pattern of contrasting parallels. Asa’s growing prosperity (14:2–7) is balanced by the concluding section on his illness and death (16:11–14). The main section concerns warfare, prophetic encouragement, and the royal response (14:8–15:19 and 16:1–10). The historian contrasts the results of relying on God (15:8–19) with the results of relying on human power (16:2 note; 20:20 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 14:2
rsbNotes.text: 14:2 Asa. Reigned from 911 to 870 b.c.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 14:3
rsbNotes.text: 14:3 took away . . . the high places. Asa removed pagan high places from both Jerusalem and “all the cities of Judah” (14:5), but 15:17 (1 Kin. 15:14) indicates that these initial efforts were not continued throughout his life. A similar explanation holds for the descriptions of Jehoshaphat’s removal of high places (cf. 17:6; 20:33).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 14:4
rsbNotes.text:
14:4 seek the Lord. See note 7:14.

keep the law and the commandment. See note 1 Chr. 16:40.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 14:6
rsbNotes.text:
14:6 He had no war. Apparently, this means that there were no major wars in this period. The writer says later that Asa had captured some towns in Ephraim during this time (15:8).

the Lord gave him peace. Chronicles presents peace in Asa’s reign as a blessing for devotion and obedience to God (14:2–16:14 note; 1 Chr. 22:9 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 14:6–7
rsbNotes.text: 14:6, 7 He built . . . Let us build. God also assisted Asa’s building projects (1 Chr. 11:5 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 14:7
rsbNotes.text: 14:7 because we have sought the Lord. Asa plainly said that his success came from having sought God (v. 4).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 14:8–15
rsbNotes.text: 14:8–15 When Zerah attacked, Asa sought the Lord and gained victory, fulfilling Solomon’s request in his prayer (6:34 note). This battle directly contrasts with Asa’s later battle against Baasha (16:1–6; see note 14:2–16:14).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 14:8
rsbNotes.text: 14:8 Asa’s army totaled 580,000. The attacking army was nearly twice as large (“a million men,” v. 9). On these large numbers, see note 1 Chr. 12:23.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 14:9
rsbNotes.text:
14:9 Zerah the Ethiopian. Possibly a general of Pharaoh Osorkon I, second ruler of the twenty-second dynasty of Egypt. “Ethiopia” in the Bible is the remote region south of Egypt, including parts of modern Eritrea, Ethiopia, and Sudan.

a million men. See 1 Chr. 19:7 note.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 14:11
rsbNotes.text:
14:11 weak. Asa expressed his utter inadequacy for battle against Zerah (20:12 note).

we rely on you. Reliance on the Lord’s power was the key to Asa’s victory (16:2 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 15:1–7
rsbNotes.text: 15:1–7 Azariah proclaims the principle of retribution so often illustrated in this account of the divided monarchy. Faithfulness to God will bring blessing; disloyalty will result in chastisement.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 15:2
rsbNotes.text: 15:2 If you seek him. See notes 7:14 and 1 Chr. 28:9.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 15:4
rsbNotes.text: 15:4 turned to the Lord. See note 7:14.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 15:8–19
rsbNotes.text: 15:8–19 Asa responded to the prophets with further reforms (v. 8) and an assembly of covenant renewal (vv. 9–15); he went so far as to depose Maacah, his relative, because of her religious apostasy (vv. 16–19).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 15:9
rsbNotes.text: 15:9 deserted to him. Israelites from the northern tribes (11:14 note) defected and joined Asa as he suppressed idolatry and reestablished worship in Jerusalem.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 15:12
rsbNotes.text: 15:12 entered into a covenant. Covenant renewal here continues God’s relationship with His people through the generations. Asa (15:12), Jehoiada (23:16), Hezekiah (29:10), and Josiah (34:30–32) lead the nation in such renewals.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 15:13
rsbNotes.text: 15:13 put to death. The Law of Moses prescribed capital punishment for those who sought other gods (Ex. 22:20; Deut. 13:6–16).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 15:15
rsbNotes.text: 15:15 rest all around. See note 1 Chr. 22:9.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 15:17
rsbNotes.text: 15:17 all his days. See note 14:3.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 15:19
rsbNotes.text: 15:19 no more war. See note 14:6.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 15:19–16:1
rsbNotes.text: 15:19–16:1 thirty-fifth year . . . thirty-sixth year. Kings reports that Elah succeeded Baasha in Asa’s 26th year (1 Kin. 15:33; 16:8), Zimri in Asa’s 27th year (1 Kin. 16:10, 15) and Omri in Asa’s 31st year (1 Kin. 16:23). Consequently, this battle could not have taken place in the 36th year of Asa (16:1) since Baasha would have been dead for ten years. No simple solution to this difficulty has been found.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 16:1–6
rsbNotes.text: 16:1–6 Asa’s battle with Baasha of Israel began his downfall. He sought the assistance of Ben-hadad of Syria, in sharp contrast with his battle against Zerah when he relied on the Lord (14:2–16:14 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 16:2
rsbNotes.text: 16:2 treasures of the house of the Lord . . . to Ben-hadad. Asa’s actions were wrong on two counts. He took from the temple treasuries, showing disregard for the temple and its worship (cf. 28:21). Second, he allied himself with a foreign power instead of relying on the Lord. The historian demonstrates the benefits of relying on God many times (1 Chr. 5:20; 2 Chr. 13:18; 14:11–15; 16:7, 8; 32:20–22). He also deplores foreign alliances and points to their dire consequences (18:1; 19:2; 20:35–37; 22:3–9; 25:7; 28:16–21; 35:21 note), a suitable warning to those engaged in rebuilding the nation following the return from exile in Babylonia.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 16:7–10
rsbNotes.text: 16:7–10 In contrast to the earlier episode of Azariah’s encouragement and Asa’s reforms (ch. 15), Hanani now rebuked King Asa, who reacted negatively (14:2–16:14 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 16:7
rsbNotes.text: 16:7 escaped you. Baasha deserted his position before the arrival of Asa and Ben-hadad, cutting short Asa’s victory (16:5).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 16:8
rsbNotes.text: 16:8 Were not the Ethiopians. Hanani referred directly to the contrast with Asa’s victory over Zerah (14:8–15). “Ethiopians” means people from south of Egypt. The Libyans were from north Africa.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 16:9
rsbNotes.text: 16:9 from now on you will have wars. Hanani threatens divine judgment because of Asa’s infidelity (1 Chr. 28:9 note; 2 Chr. 14:6 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 16:10
rsbNotes.text: 16:10 some of the people. Presumably those who agreed with Hanani the prophet.

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 16:11–14
rsbNotes.text: 16:11–14 Asa’s rejection of the prophetic word led to his disease and death (14:2–16:14 note).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 16:12
rsbNotes.text: 16:12 physicians. Asa continued to turn away from the Lord and rely on human strength. The Old Testament does not hesitate to prescribe medical treatment for physical maladies (2 Kin. 20:5–7 and the use of balm in Jer. 8:22; 51:8), but it never divorces natural remedies from seeking divine assistance (Deut. 32:39).

rsbNotes.title: 2 Chr 16:14
rsbNotes.text: 16:14 made a very great fire in his honor. These fires were not cremations, but memorials honoring deceased kings. Contrast the honor bestowed on Asa with the response to Jehoram’s death (21:19).
